{{disambig-two|the people|region also called "Forodwaith"|[[Northern Waste]]}}

The '''Forodwaith''' were a people of [[Men]] who dwelt in the far north of [[Middle-earth]], apparently dating back to the [[Elder Days]]. Not much is known about them.

==History==
The Forodwaith were noted as being a hardy people, accustomed to cold, as indeed would be necessary living in the icy lands close to [[Morgoth]]'s realm.<ref name="Lossoth">{{App|Eriador}}, entry for king Arvedui, footnote about the Lossoth, p. 1041</ref> The land they lived in was called [[Northern Waste|Forodwaith]], after its inhabitants.<ref>{{UT|IMap}}, footnote for ''Forodwaith''</ref>

By the [[Third Age]], the [[Lossoth]], a remnant of the Forodwaith, lived mostly on the great [[Cape of Forochel]] north-west of the [[Icebay of Forochel]]. However, they often set up their camps on the southern shore of the bay at the feet of the [[Blue Mountains|Mountains]].<ref name="Lossoth" /> The region north of the [[Mountains of Angmar]] and the [[Grey Mountains]] was still called Forodwaith on maps of Middle-earth at the end of the Third Age.<ref>{{UT|Map}}</ref><ref>{{FR|Map}}</ref>

==Etymology==
''Forodwaith'' is a [[Sindarin]] name, which means "Northmen".<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}}, entries '''WEG-''' and '''PHOR-</ref> It is a combination of the element ''[[forod]]''<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}}, entry '''PHOR-'''</ref> ("north")<ref>{{App|Letters}}, Note, p. 1123</ref> and the element ''[[gwaith]]''<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}}, entry '''WEG-'''</ref> ("people" associated by place and occupation)<ref>{{PE|17}}, entry root WĒ, pp. 189-90</ref>.

==Other versions of the legendarium==
In some drafts about [[Ælfwine]], Tolkien uses the word ''Forodwaith'' to refer to the [[Wikipedia:Vikings|Vikings]].<ref>{{LT2|VIb}}, p. 318</ref>
